intro: Cracca constricta, commonly known as the narrow-leaved cracca, is a flowering plant native to parts of Europe and Asia. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its aromatic, often edible leaves. The plant typically grows in moist, shady environments such as woodlands and stream banks. It produces small, yellowish flowers arranged in umbels, which are typical of the family. The leaves are narrow and lance-shaped, with a distinctive, slightly serrated edge.
